Donate
Donate
Donate Items
Learn the Do’s & Don’ts for donating to Goodwill. We accept donations of clean, useable items in sellable condition.
Attended Donation Centers
Attended Donation Centers (ADC’s) are locations that ONLY ACCEPT DONATIONS, they are not retails stores. ADC’s accept donations of textiles, housewares, and other smaller donations.
Donor Concierge
Moving to a new city, downsizing to a smaller home, or the loss of a loved one all bring tough decisions: which items to keep, which items to donate to charity, and which items to discard. Goodwill’s Donor Concierge Service Team can help guide you through this process.
Donate Vehicles
Goodwill accepts donations of cars, trucks, RVs, motorcycles, and boats, which are then re-sold at auction to fund our programs and services for people with disabilities and other disadvantages.
Financial Gifts
Your financial gift is an investment in transformation and lasting change. Give By Bequest, Give By Check, Give By Donor – Advised Fund, Give By Stock Or IRA Charitable Distribution, or Sponsor an Event.
Volunteer Your Time
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida utilizes volunteers for numerous activities throughout the year. Meet new people, help your community and learn a new skill!
Tax Deductions
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida Is An IRS-Approved 501(c)(3) Nonprofit Organization. This means donations to Goodwill are often tax deductible!
–
When you donate to Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, you help the planet and our local community. Your donation of gently used household items extends the life of useful goods by keeping them out of landfills.

Store Locator
Goodwill SWFL is more than just a thrift store. We offer more than affordable finds—we create opportunities. Every purchase and donation helps support our mission to empower people with disabilities and other challenges to find meaningful work and greater independence.

Goodwill’s values reflect a commitment to our mission and vision focused on serving the and empowering individuals while striving for recognition as a leader and resource in the community.
About
History
Goodwill Industries was founded in 1902 in Boston, Massachusetts by Rev. Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister and early social innovator. Helms collected used household goods and clothing in wealthier areas of the city, then trained and hired those who were poor to mend and repair the used goods.
Leadership
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Inc. is operated autonomously and governed by a dedicated local volunteer Board of Directors, which advises the leadership team on the overall operation of the nonprofit organization
Mission
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida is committed to serving people with disabilities and disadvantages by offering life-changing opportunities to achieve independence.
Tours
Go behind the scenes at our Opportunity Center and see how your donations and your community partnership changes lives.
Success Stories
We serve over 24,000 individuals every year. Here are some of their stories.

Housing
HOME  / SERVICES / Housing
Southwest Florida GWI Housing, Inc. provides income-sensitive, barrier-free housing for people with physical disabilities, providing the opportunity for affordable, convenient, independent living to enhance their overall quality of life.
Accessible & Affordable Housing
Goodwill’s HUD-approved apartment complexes are specifically designed to accommodate people with disabilities. The one and two bedroom apartments are constructed with conveniences like lowered sinks, countertops, mirrors, accessible appliances, and easy roll-in showers. Each complex has a laundry room and an on-site community room or picnic/patio area. All of our apartment complexes are built in areas with easy access to public transportation, shopping centers, banks, and schools.
Goodwill currently provides housing for people with disabilities in Cape Coral, Clewiston, Fort Myers, LaBelle, Lehigh Acres, North Fort Myers, Port Charlotte, and Punta Gorda.
View PDF about our Goodwill Housing Services
Hatton B. Rogers Retirement Community
This 54-unit North Fort Myers apartment complex provides income-subsidized housing for
seniors 62 years or older
. Residents do not have to have a physical disability to qualify for occupancy and must be able to live independently.
Goodwill partners with
Senior Friendship Centers of Lee County
to provide meals and activities for Hatton B. Rogers residents.
Call (239) 995-6100 to Apply for Housing
All applicants must meet medical and income requirements.
All applicants must pass a background check in order to be considered for residency.
Because of high demand for disability accessible apartments, our complexes have waiting lists. Applicants must provide all necessary documentation before being placed on a waiting list.

DISABILITY SERVICES
HOME / SERVICES / DISABILITY SERVICES
Goodwill has more than a century of experience at helping people with disabilities and other barriers to employment.
Let us help you take the Next Step Forward!
Pathways to Opportunity
Pathways to Opportunity is a day training program for adults with disabilities. The program offers group classes taught by trained professionals, focusing on life skills development.
Disability Navigation
The Disability Navigation Program guides individuals and families through the  Medicaid Waiver (iBudget) and Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD) services and application process. Fill out form for more information.
Pathways to Work
Employment Services and Supported Employment both include job placement and job coaching with Supported Employment providing continuing assistance to succeed at work.

ABOUT US
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Ic.
Our History
Our Mission
Success Stories
Our Team
We Are More Than Our Stores
While Goodwill is best known for our popular retail thrift stores, they only scratch the surface of our story. We accept and sell donated items for multiple reasons and with many benefits!
Our stores generate revenue that allow Goodwill to offer free employment and career services.
93¢ of every dollar earned in our retail stores supports programs and services.
Many Southwest Floridians want to work, but they need help identifying their skills or abilities, finding employment, and learning how to succeed long-term.
Goodwill provides services to job seekers, those who want to advance in their career (including our own employees), and employers throughout our area who need to fill permanent, full-time positions that offer benefits and a career path.
Thanks to our retail stores,
Goodwill diverts about 30 million pounds of items from our landfills every year.
Many items that can’t be offered for sale in our stores or online are sold for recycling, further funding our programs and services.
5 Fun Facts You Should Know about Goodwill SWFL!
1
This is John, our CEO.
Like other nonprofits, Goodwill is managed by respected business leaders and a volunteer board of directors which provides guidance. Goodwill isn’t “owned” by anybody.
Our CEO, John Nadeau, has been with Goodwill for more than 13 years holding senior-level management positions throughout his career. Nadeau also has 23 years of extensive experience running and operating an upscale retail grocery store. Nadeau’s combined years of experiences make him very proficient in both the nonprofit and for-profit sectors.
Is he making a million dollars each year? No, but he is fairly compensated for someone who has a great deal of experience and the responsibility of managing more than 1000 employees and ensuring that one of Southwest Florida’s largest nonprofits is fulfilling its mission.
2
Our stores are designed to support our mission services.
A lot of folks think our stores are just places that sell used items to people who have low incomes. While we’re happy we can provide affordable goods, our stores do so much more. When we sell those items, the money we raise goes toward the many programs and services we provide in Southwest Florida.
So, just like a hospital auxiliary thrift store helps the community through the hospital, a Goodwill store helps the community through all of those services that Goodwill provides.
3
93¢ of every dollar we earn goes back to our mission.
any charities spend a high percentage of their income on overhead and fundraising. We don’t. When you shop in our stores or
donate
to Goodwill, 93% of that money goes back into our
mission services.
Sure, overhead expense isn’t the only way to judge a responsible charity, but it is important. And so is this: Guidestar by Candid, which rates nonprofits for donors and grantors, gives us their top rating – Platinum.
Nationwide,
Goodwill is rated an “A” grade by Charity Watch
, and for the last 5 years has been named one of the country’s
“20 Most Inspiring Companies” in Forbes Magazine.
4
This year, we helped someone you know.
Maybe their son or daughter attends our
Pathways to Opportunity
adult day-training. Maybe we helped them write a resume or we showed them how to interview for a job. Maybe they were at risk of dropping out of school and we helped them explore vocational careers. Maybe they attended our small business training
MicroEnterprise
courses. Or maybe they live in one of our safe, affordable apartments.
Last year, our many programs and services helped more than 23,000 folks here in Southwest Florida.
5
All of our employees in SWFL earn at least the federal minimum wage.
That applies to every one of our 1,000+ employees, who earn the Florida State minimum wage.
While some Goodwill organizations are among the 3,400 employers nationwide that use the federal minimum wage exemption to provide employment support to people with very severe disabilities, here in Southwest Florida, we do not.
(Read more about how some Goodwill agencies utilize the exemption).

Donate Items
Learn the Do’s & Don’ts for donating to Goodwill. We accept donations of clean, useable items in sellable condition.
Attended Donation Centers
Attended Donation Centers (ADC’s) are locations that ONLY ACCEPT DONATIONS, they are not retails stores. ADC’s accept donations of textiles, housewares, and other smaller donations.
Donor Concierge
Moving to a new city, downsizing to a smaller home, or the loss of a loved one all bring tough decisions: which items to keep, which items to donate to charity, and which items to discard. Goodwill’s Donor Concierge Service Team can help guide you through this process.
Donate Vehicles
Goodwill accepts donations of cars, trucks, RVs, motorcycles, and boats, which are then re-sold at auction to fund our programs and services for people with disabilities and other disadvantages.
Financial Gifts
Your financial gift is an investment in transformation and lasting change. Give By Bequest, Give By Check, Give By Donor – Advised Fund, Give By Stock Or IRA Charitable Distribution, or Sponsor an Event.
Volunteer Your Time
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida utilizes volunteers for numerous activities throughout the year. Meet new people, help your community and learn a new skill!
Tax Deductions
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida Is An IRS-Approved 501(c)(3) Nonprofit Organization. This means donations to Goodwill are often tax deductible!

About
History
Goodwill Industries was founded in 1902 in Boston, Massachusetts by Rev. Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister and early social innovator. Helms collected used household goods and clothing in wealthier areas of the city, then trained and hired those who were poor to mend and repair the used goods.
Leadership
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Inc. is operated autonomously and governed by a dedicated local volunteer Board of Directors, which advises the leadership team on the overall operation of the nonprofit organization
Mission
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida is committed to serving people with disabilities and disadvantages by offering life-changing opportunities to achieve independence.

Locations
Empowering Your Future at Goodwill’s Community Resource Centers
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida’s Community Resource Centers (CRCs) are here to help individuals take charge of their future. Whether you’re looking to gain new skills, advance your career, or access essential services, our CRCs provide the tools and support you need—all at no cost to you.
Build Skills & Advance Your Career
At our Community Resource Centers, we offer:
Digital Training
Learn essential computer and technology skills.
Certifications & Credentials
Earn qualifications to boost your career.
Career Planning
Explore pathways to a fulfilling profession.
Resume Assistance
Craft a resume that stands out.
Interview Preparation
Gain confidence and polish your skills.
Employer Connections
Connect with hiring companies in your community.
Financial Literacy
Learn how to manage your money and plan for financial success.
Connect to Community Resources
CRCs also provide
connections to the following
:
Veteran Services
Support and programs for those who have served.
Unemployment Services
Assistance with job searches and benefits.
English as a Second Language (ESL)
Improve language skills for work and daily life.
Income Tax Preparation
Get help filing your taxes.
Food Pantry Assistance
Access nutritious food for you and your family.
Housing & Rental Assistance
Find support for stable housing. ACCESS Florida, SNAP, & Medicaid
FAFSA & Educational Support
Get help applying for financial aid for education.
The Mobile Community Resource Center (CRC) is helping people move
FORWARD
with free resources and services that promote long-term employment and self-sufficiency.
Mobile Community Resource Center
Goodwill’s Mobile CRC
collaborates with community partners providing food distribution, VITA (tax preparation), and employment assistance through hiring events.
The versatile bus has
six computer stations
that provide employment opportunities and other wrap-around services to areas of need in the community.
The Mobile Unit was acquired through
Collier Cares
and the
American Cares Act
.
It serves the
five county areas
of Charlotte, Collier, Glades, Hendry, and Lee.
The Mobile CRC provides the same services as our Community Resource Centers,
only it’s on wheels!
Digital Training & Certifications
Goodwill is working hard to be accessible to all who wish to further their education by offering a strong start for those looking to begin or change their career.
Goodwill is committed to making education and career advancement accessible to all. Through our Digital Training & Certifications programs, we provide individuals with the foundational skills needed to succeed in today’s job market. Whether you’re looking to sharpen your digital literacy, earn industry-recognized certifications, or explore a new career path, Goodwill offers flexible, supportive training to help you take the next step with confidence. With hands-on learning and expert guidance, we’re here to equip you with the tools to build a brighter future.
Play Video
Hermelinda Herrera
– Goodwill Digital Learner
GIVE: Goodwill Investing in Valued Employees
GIVE is Goodwill’s employee support and development program, designed to help team members overcome challenges and grow in their careers. Our Program Coordinator offers personalized, wrap-around support to address barriers like transportation, housing, family responsibilities, and financial stress.
Digital Skills (basic and job-specific)
English as a Second Language (ESL) classes
Career coaching for advancement
GIVE empowers employees to succeed — at work and beyond.
Digital Skills Training
A skilled workforce knowledgeable in digital skills is necessary in today’s competitive workforce.  Our CRC’s offer free on-site digital training to help bridge the skills gap that many job seekers face.
Our digital skills courses are free and include everything from basic to advanced computer training, Internet navigation, social media, word processing, spreadsheet software, and even typing courses.
Certifications
Goodwill also offers entry-level
training and certification opportunities
to Southwest Florida job seekers in the following areas:
English As A Second Language (ESL)
and
Home Healthcare

Opportunity Accelerator™
offers workshop format services to help job seekers gain employability skills to become more marketable in their career journeys. For location specific dates and times, please refer to each site’s weekly schedule.

Success Stories
Margarita Florencio
Lehigh Acres Community Resource Center
Margarita Florencio came to the Lehigh Acres Goodwill Community Resource Center (CRC) looking for assistance with FEMA and ACCESS applications. She also needed a job. The coordinators helped her with her applications, and also assisted her with acquiring employment at the Goodwill retail store in Lehigh. Through a referral by the Lehigh Acres CRC staff, Margarita was hired as a part-time processor. Through her dedication and exemplary work ethic, she swiftly earned a promotion to a full-time position within a year. Simultaneously, she actively participated in our Citizenship class, showcasing her commitment to personal and professional development. On March 28th, she graciously shared her naturalization certificate with us, marking a significant milestone – one step closer to reaching her goals.

About
History
Goodwill Industries was founded in 1902 in Boston, Massachusetts by Rev. Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister and early social innovator. Helms collected used household goods and clothing in wealthier areas of the city, then trained and hired those who were poor to mend and repair the used goods.
Leadership
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Inc. is operated autonomously and governed by a dedicated local volunteer Board of Directors, which advises the leadership team on the overall operation of the nonprofit organization
Mission
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida is committed to serving people with disabilities and disadvantages by offering life-changing opportunities to achieve independence.

TRUTH ABOUT GOODWILL AND Q&A
HOME / ABOUT US / TRUTH ABOUT GOODWILL
Truth About Goodwill and Q&A
Our Response to Misinformation
Your donations to Goodwill’s Retail & Donation Centers and your financial contributions to Goodwill SWFL fund programs and services that assist tens of thousands of Southwest Floridians each year.
Unfortunately, we sometimes stand in the line of fire from individuals and organizations who are misinformed and/or misrepresent us to the public.
This negative rumor mill has resurfaced in the form of a six year old email that includes a variation of a message like this:
“Think about these before you donate. As you open your pockets to do a good thing and make yourself feel good, please keep these facts in mind…”
The message then quotes erroneous information and salary figures for several nonprofit organizations’ chief executives, including a reference to a so-called,
“Goodwill CEO and Owner Mark Curran, who profits $2.3 million a year.”
This information is erroneous.
Goodwill has more than a century of experience at helping people with disabilities and other barriers to employment in the U.S., Canada, and 13 other countries. Goodwill is a leading social services enterprise, and consistently ranks among the nation’s top charities.
We Are A Nonprofit Organization
Neither Goodwill Industries International nor Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida are
“owned”
by anyone. Steven C. Preston is the actual CEO of Goodwill Industries International and reports to a volunteer Board of Directors. Locally, John Nadeau is the President & CEO of Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida. He, too, reports to a volunteer Board of Directors.
Here in Southwest Florida,
approximately $.93 cents of every dollar is spent on our mission services
. This is a very healthy number in the nonprofit world, and a solid indicator of our commitment to good stewardship of your donations. Goodwill adheres to a strong Corporate Compliance philosophy that demonstrates what our organization stands for, including its ethical, social, and environmental values.
Corporate Compliance Manual for Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Inc.
That is the one legitimate message this damaging hoax email contains. We also suggest that you
learn more about the charities you’d like to support
. Make sure the organization you choose uses its revenue for charitable purposes that support a mission you believe in.
We encourage you to
visit Candid’s GuideStar website
,
which posts financial records and independent reviews of charities. There, you can review our IRS 990 form, required of most federally tax-exempt organizations. Goodwill Industries International is certified with the GuideStar Exchange Seal for its commitment to transparency.
For more information debunking this hoax email,
visit Snopes
, a website dedicated to validating or debunking urban legends, Internet rumors, email forwards, and other stories of unknown or questionable origin.
Goodwill Certainly Encourages You to “Think Before You Donate”

MISSION SERVICES
HOME / MISSION SERVICES
How does Goodwill help people in Southwest Florida?
Goodwill provides numerous programs and services in Charlotte, Collier, Glades, Hendry, and Lee, counties to help people become more independent and self-sufficient.
These programs include educational initiatives. We offer job readiness training through our
Community Resource Centers
and the
Pathways to Work
supported employment program.
We provide small business training through the
Goodwill SWFL MicroEnterprise Institute
. Goodwill operates 16 income-subsidized
disability-accessible housing
complexes.
Goodwill’s Digital Training
courses help people get employment training or certifications for free, as well as provide community outreach services.
Adults with disabilities gain opportunities to become more independent through our adult day training program
Pathways to Opportunity
.
Goodwill SWFL mission-based Community Support Services programs are supported by the resale of donated goods in our stores and grants, donations, and contracts. Those supporting programs in 2024 are listed below in alphabetical order, grouped by the amount of funds provided. These programs are not possible without their support.
A special thank you to those who provided grant support in 2023 for our Mission Services.
Resource Centers
Information & Training
Wrap-Around Services
comprehensive support

business training

What Is A “Barrier to Employment?”
A barrier to employment is
any disadvantage which prevents individuals from gaining or maintaining employment
. These barriers may include but are not limited to a lack of education, age, physical or mental disabilities, lack of computer access, language barriers, and economic constraints.

OUR MISSION
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida is
committed to serving people
with disabilities and disadvantages by offering life-changing opportunities to achieve independence.
OUR VISION
To be recognized as a valued leader and resource for people with disabilities and other barriers to employment in the communities we serve.
OUR VALUES
Empowerment
Providing tools, resources, and support to empower individuals with disabilities and disadvantages to achieve independence.
Community Engagement
Actively engaging with the community to understand and address the needs of people with disabilities and other barriers to employment.
Opportunity
Creating life-changing opportunities for personal and professional growth through education, training, and employment programs.
Advocacy
Advocating for the rights and equal opportunities of individuals with disabilities and disadvantages within the workforce and society at large.
Collaboration
Collaborating with local organizations, businesses, and government agencies to create comprehensive solutions and support systems for individuals facing barriers to employment.
Transparency
Providing clear and transparent information about programs, services, and outcomes to stakeholders, including clients, donors, and the community.
Quality
Delivering high-quality services and programs that meet the unique needs of individuals with disabilities and disadvantages.
Respect
Treating all individuals with dignity, respect, and compassion, recognizing their inherent worth and potential.
Innovation
Embracing innovation and continuous improvement to develop new strategies and approaches that better serve individuals with disabilities and disadvantages
We Are More Than Our Stores
While Goodwill is best known for our popular retail thrift stores, they only scratch the surface of our story. We accept and sell donated items for multiple reasons and with many benefits!
Our stores generate revenue that allow Goodwill to offer free employment and career services.
93¢ of every dollar earned in our retail stores supports programs and services.
Many Southwest Floridians want to work, but they need help identifying their skills or abilities, finding employment, and learning how to succeed long-term.
Goodwill provides services to job seekers, those who want to advance in their career (including our own employees), and employers throughout our area who need to fill permanent, full-time positions that offer benefits and a career path.
Thanks to our retail stores,
Goodwill diverts about 30 million pounds of items from our landfills every year.
Many items that can’t be offered for sale in our stores or online are sold for recycling, further funding our programs and services.

Tax Deductions
Your vehicle donation will help Goodwill provide people with life changing opportunities to achieve independence.
What to Expect When Donating Vehicles
Goodwill accepts donations of cars, trucks, RVs, motorcycles, and boats, which are then resold at auction to fund our programs and services for people with disabilities and other disadvantages.
Donate your car in 3 easy steps:
1
Complete the Form
Fill out the online vehicle donation form or call our 24/7 Goodwill Car Donations Phone Line at (866) 492-2770.
2
Schedule
We arrange a time within 24 – 48 hours to pick up your vehicle at your convenience. Towing is always free.
3
Receive Tax Deduction
We send you your tax deduction information in the mail.
Reasons to Donate Your Car to Goodwill
Free local towing
Fast pickup
We accept all vehicles, running or not
Your donation may be
tax deductible
(consult a tax advisor for specifics)
Recycling saves energy and natural resources
Simple process
Hassle-free paperwork
How to Donate Your Car
To donate to Goodwill, your vehicle must be titled in your name and completely paid, although we will accept vehicles with proper lien releases from financial institutions. Title questions or concerns? Give us a call at
(866) 492-2770
and we’d be happy to help answer any questions you may have.
Donating a vehicle to Goodwill is a donor-friendly process. You can either drop it off during regular operating hours,
fill out our online donation form
, or contact our customer service department at
(866) 492-2770
to have your vehicle towed free of charge. Goodwill offers fast and free pick up. Please remember to remove your license plates and all personal items from the vehicle before it is donated. Finally, when donating your vehicle, please make sure to have your vehicle title with you.
You will receive a donation receipt at the time of donation. Please take a copy of the donation receipt, your license plates, and vehicle registration to the Department of Motor Vehicles to de-register the car as soon as possible. Once the vehicle is de-registered, contact your insurance company to cancel coverage (they also may want a copy of the donation receipt). You will also need your documentation to claim your donation as a charitable contribution on your
federal income taxes
.
Donate a
Boat, RV, Motorcycle, & More
In addition to autos, Goodwill also accepts many other types of vehicles, including boats, RVs, motorcycles, fleet vehicles, riding lawn mowers, jet skis, and more!
Don’t see your vehicle type listed here? Fill out our online donation form or give our customer service department a call at
(866) 492-2770
for more information.
* Alien spacecraft not accepted
and should be donated to NASA *

Goodwill’s values reflect a commitment to our mission and vision focused on serving the and empowering individuals while striving for recognition as a leader and resource in the community.
About
History
Goodwill Industries was founded in 1902 in Boston, Massachusetts by Rev. Edgar J. Helms, a Methodist minister and early social innovator. Helms collected used household goods and clothing in wealthier areas of the city, then trained and hired those who were poor to mend and repair the used goods.
Leadership
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, Inc. is operated autonomously and governed by a dedicated local volunteer Board of Directors, which advises the leadership team on the overall operation of the nonprofit organization
Mission
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida is committed to serving people with disabilities and disadvantages by offering life-changing opportunities to achieve independence.

Donate
Donate Items
Learn the Do’s & Don’ts for donating to Goodwill. We accept donations of clean, useable items in sellable condition.
Attended Donation Centers
Attended Donation Centers (ADC’s) are locations that ONLY ACCEPT DONATIONS, they are not retails stores. ADC’s accept donations of textiles, housewares, and other smaller donations.
Donor Concierge
Moving to a new city, downsizing to a smaller home, or the loss of a loved one all bring tough decisions: which items to keep, which items to donate to charity, and which items to discard. Goodwill’s Donor Concierge Service Team can help guide you through this process.
Donate Vehicles
Goodwill accepts donations of cars, trucks, RVs, motorcycles, and boats, which are then re-sold at auction to fund our programs and services for people with disabilities and other disadvantages.
Financial Gifts
Your financial gift is an investment in transformation and lasting change. Give By Bequest, Give By Check, Give By Donor – Advised Fund, Give By Stock Or IRA Charitable Distribution, or Sponsor an Event.
Volunteer Your Time
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida utilizes volunteers for numerous activities throughout the year. Meet new people, help your community and learn a new skill!
Tax Deductions
Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida Is An IRS-Approved 501(c)(3) Nonprofit Organization. This means donations to Goodwill are often tax deductible!
–
When you donate to Goodwill Industries of Southwest Florida, you help the planet and our local community. Your donation of gently used household items extends the life of useful goods by keeping them out of landfills.

Leave It to Us
Letting go of things can be difficult. Moving to a new city, downsizing to a smaller home, or the loss of a loved one all bring tough decisions: which items to keep, which items to donate to charity, and which items to discard.
Goodwill’s Donor Concierge Service Team
can help guide you through this process.
Our team will:
Come to your location (limited locations in Collier & Lee counties).
Assess the size and quality of your donation.
Pack your donations with care and transport them to Goodwill.
To make an appointment with our Goodwill Donor Concierge Service Team, please call
(239) 271-7168
or email us at
donations@goodwillswfl.org
.
Goodwill’s Donor Concierge service is
FREE
, and you will be provided with both peace of mind and a donation receipt for tax purposes. Your generosity will change lives right here in Southwest Florida.
“Thank you so very much for this service and the execution that took place in both packing and moving all the items we donated!”
– Tracy

Calling All Retired Medical Professionals!
Are you ready to share your knowledge and experience with the next generation of healthcare workers? We’re looking for retired nurses, medical assistants, and other healthcare professionals to volunteer as mentors for individuals exploring careers as Certified Nursing Assistants (CNAs) and Medical Assistants (MAs). Your insight can make a lasting difference in someone’s journey into the medical field. Join us in shaping the future of compassionate care.
Help teach those interested in being a:
Certified Nursing Assitant (CNA)
Medical Assistant (MA)

SWFL MicroEnterprise

.
All of our volunteers proudly follow our Corporate Compliance policies. Here in Southwest Florida, approximately
$.93 cents of every dollar
is spent on our mission services. This is a very healthy number in the nonprofit world, and a solid indicator of our commitment to good stewardship of your donations. Goodwill adheres to a strong Corporate Compliance philosophy that demonstrates what our organization stands for, including its ethical, social, and environmental values.
Goodwill Volunteers Share Their Stories
Soy Williams volunteers her time at Goodwill to curate the collection and sale of fine art at the blue Boutiques in Downtown Fort Myers and Ave Maria. She oversees the distribution of all the art, directing each piece to maximize the benefit to Goodwill mission services.
Soy believes in honoring the donations of our generous donors and preserving the legacy of fine art. "Part of what we want to do with fine art is elevate everyone's shopping experience by paying more attention to it, featuring it, and giving it some extra attention," explains Soy. "Also, people that donate things to us, and we sell them, and we honor it by selling them at a good price. It gives them an opportunity to see where their contributions are actually working to help the mission."
Soy Williams
2021 Breakthrough Volunteer
Steven is dedicating to making a difference, reserving several days a week to focus on MicroEnterprise. He says, volunteering as a coach is very rewarding.
"I've been a coach now for over 5 years. I will tell you that it has been satisfying, it has been fun, it has been challenging," laughed Steve. "And, when the teaching team goes home at night, we are in high spirits. As we are walking out the door, there is a smile on everyone's face and we are sharing little quips. It's fun."
Steven Johnson
MicroEnterprise/2020 Breakthrough Volunteer
"We look forward to the event every year," say the three sisters on Festival of Trees.
All three sisters love dogs and eagerly volunteer helping shelter animals. And they'll be back for more at the next Festival of Trees!
